full.title: Enhancement of Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub> (M = Sn, Pb) Electrodes for Lithium- and Sodium-Ion Batteries by Structure Disordering and CNTs Additives.
full.authorString: Pavlyuk V, Ciesielski W, Pavlyuk N, Kulawik D, Balińska A, Kluziak K.

full.abstractText: The maximally disordered (MD) phases with the general formula Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub> (M = Sn, Pb) are formed with partial substitution of Y by Pr and Sb by Sn or Pb in the binary Y<sub>5</sub>Sb<sub>3</sub> compound. During the electrochemical lithiation and sodiation, the formation of Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub>Li<sub>z</sub> and Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub>Na<sub>z</sub> maximally disordered-high entropy intermetallic phases (MD-HEIP), as the result of insertion of Li/Na into octahedral voids, were observed. Carbon nanotubes (CNT) are an effective additive to improve the cycle stability of the Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub> (M = Sn, Pb) anodes for lithium-ion (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Modification of Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>Sn<sub>y</sub> alloys by carbon nanotubes allowed us to significantly increase the discharge capacity of both types of batteries, which reaches 280 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for LIBs) and 160 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for SIBs), respectively. For Y<sub>5-x</sub>PrxSb<sub>3-y</sub>Pb<sub>y</sub> alloys in which antimony is replaced by lead, these capacities are slightly smaller and are 270 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for LIBs) and 155 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for SIBs), respectively. Results show that structure disordering and CNT additives could increase the electrode capacities up to 30% for LIBs and up to 25% for SIBs.
full.affiliation: Institute of Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Technology, Częstochowa Jan Długosz University, al. Armii Krajowej 13/15, 42200 Częstochowa, Poland.

abstract: The maximally disordered (MD) phases with the general formula Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub> (M = Sn, Pb) are formed with partial substitution of Y by Pr and Sb by Sn or Pb in the binary Y<sub>5</sub>Sb<sub>3</sub> compound. During the electrochemical lithiation and sodiation, the formation of Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub>Li<sub>z</sub> and Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub>Na<sub>z</sub> maximally disordered-high entropy intermetallic phases (MD-HEIP), as the result of insertion of Li/Na into octahedral voids, were observed. Carbon nanotubes (CNT) are an effective additive to improve the cycle stability of the Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub> (M = Sn, Pb) anodes for lithium-ion (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Modification of Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>Sn<sub>y</sub> alloys by carbon nanotubes allowed us to significantly increase the discharge capacity of both types of batteries, which reaches 280 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for LIBs) and 160 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for SIBs), respectively. For Y<sub>5-x</sub>PrxSb<sub>3-y</sub>Pb<sub>y</sub> alloys in which antimony is replaced by lead, these capacities are slightly smaller and are 270 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for LIBs) and 155 mAh · g<sup>-1</sup> (for SIBs), respectively. Results show that structure disordering and CNT additives could increase the electrode capacities up to 30% for LIBs and up to 25% for SIBs.
title: Enhancement of Y<sub>5-x</sub>Pr<sub>x</sub>Sb<sub>3-y</sub>M<sub>y</sub> (M = Sn, Pb) Electrodes for Lithium- and Sodium-Ion Batteries by Structure Disordering and CNTs Additives.
